docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizersMixin
docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withName
docs.text:
withName(name)

"Name must be unique within a namespace. Is required when creating resources, although some resources may allow a client to request the generation of an appropriate name automatically. Name is primarily intended for creation idempotence and configuration definition. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#names"

docs.title: fn metadata.withNamespace
docs.text:
withNamespace(namespace)

"Namespace defines the space within which each name must be unique. An empty namespace is equivalent to the \"default\" namespace, but \"default\" is the canonical representation. Not all objects are required to be scoped to a namespace - the value of this field for those objects will be empty.\n\nMust be a DNS_LABEL. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/namespaces"

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferences
docs.text:

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

docs.title: fn metadata.withResourceVersion
docs.text:
withResourceVersion(resourceVersion)

"An opaque value that represents the internal version of this object that can be used by clients to determine when objects have changed. May be used for optimistic concurrency, change detection, and the watch operation on a resource or set of resources. Clients must treat these values as opaque and passed unmodified back to the server. They may only be valid for a particular resource or set of resources.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. Value must be treated as opaque by clients and . More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#concurrency-control-and-consistency"

docs.text:
withFlushInterval(flushInterval)

"FlushInterval defines the interval, in milliseconds, in between flushes to the client while copying the response body. A negative value means to flush immediately after each write to the client. This configuration is ignored when ReverseProxy recognizes a response as a streaming response; for such responses, writes are flushed to the client immediately. Default: 100ms"

If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: obj metadata
docs.text: "ObjectMeta is metadata that all persisted resources must have, which includes all objects users must create."

docs.title: fn metadata.withAnnotations
docs.text:
withAnnotations(annotations)

"Annotations is an unstructured key value map stored with a resource that may be set by external tools to store and retrieve arbitrary metadata. They are not queryable and should be preserved when modifying objects. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/annotations"

docs.title: fn metadata.withAnnotationsMixin
docs.text:
withAnnotationsMixin(annotations)

"Annotations is an unstructured key value map stored with a resource that may be set by external tools to store and retrieve arbitrary metadata. They are not queryable and should be preserved when modifying objects. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/annotations"

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withClusterName
docs.text:
withClusterName(clusterName)

"The name of the cluster which the object belongs to. This is used to distinguish resources with same name and namespace in different clusters. This field is not set anywhere right now and apiserver is going to ignore it if set in create or update request."

docs.title: fn metadata.withCreationTimestamp
docs.text:
withCreationTimestamp(creationTimestamp)

"Time is a wrapper around time.Time which supports correct marshaling to YAML and JSON. Wrappers are provided for many of the factory methods that the time package offers."

docs.title: fn metadata.withDeletionGracePeriodSeconds
docs.text:
withDeletionGracePeriodSeconds(deletionGracePeriodSeconds)

"Number of seconds allowed for this object to gracefully terminate before it will be removed from the system. Only set when deletionTimestamp is also set. May only be shortened. Read-only."

docs.title: fn metadata.withDeletionTimestamp
docs.text:
withDeletionTimestamp(deletionTimestamp)

"Time is a wrapper around time.Time which supports correct marshaling to YAML and JSON. Wrappers are provided for many of the factory methods that the time package offers."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizersMixin
docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withGeneration
docs.text:
withGeneration(generation)

"A sequence number representing a specific generation of the desired state. Populated by the system. Read-only."

docs.title: fn metadata.withLabels
docs.text:
withLabels(labels)

"Map of string keys and values that can be used to organize and categorize (scope and select) objects. May match selectors of replication controllers and services. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/labels"

docs.title: fn metadata.withLabelsMixin
docs.text:
withLabelsMixin(labels)

"Map of string keys and values that can be used to organize and categorize (scope and select) objects. May match selectors of replication controllers and services. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/labels"

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withName
docs.text:
withName(name)

"Name must be unique within a namespace. Is required when creating resources, although some resources may allow a client to request the generation of an appropriate name automatically. Name is primarily intended for creation idempotence and configuration definition. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#names"

docs.title: fn metadata.withNamespace
docs.text:
withNamespace(namespace)

"Namespace defines the space within which each name must be unique. An empty namespace is equivalent to the \"default\" namespace, but \"default\" is the canonical representation. Not all objects are required to be scoped to a namespace - the value of this field for those objects will be empty.\n\nMust be a DNS_LABEL. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/namespaces"

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferences
docs.text:
withOwnerReferences(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferencesMixin
docs.text:
withOwnerReferencesMixin(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withResourceVersion
docs.text:
withResourceVersion(resourceVersion)

"An opaque value that represents the internal version of this object that can be used by clients to determine when objects have changed. May be used for optimistic concurrency, change detection, and the watch operation on a resource or set of resources. Clients must treat these values as opaque and passed unmodified back to the server. They may only be valid for a particular resource or set of resources.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. Value must be treated as opaque by clients and . More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#concurrency-control-and-consistency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withSelfLink
docs.text:
withSelfLink(selfLink)

"SelfLink is a URL representing this object. Populated by the system. Read-only.\n\nDEPRECATED Kubernetes will stop propagating this field in 1.20 release and the field is planned to be removed in 1.21 release."

docs.title: fn metadata.withUid
docs.text:
withUid(uid)

"UID is the unique in time and space value for this object. It is typically generated by the server on successful creation of a resource and is not allowed to change on PUT operations.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#uids"

docs.title: obj spec
docs.text: "MiddlewareSpec defines the desired state of a Middleware."

docs.title: fn spec.withPlugin
docs.text:
withPlugin(plugin)

"Plugin defines the middleware plugin configuration. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/plugins/"

docs.title: fn spec.withPluginMixin
docs.text:
withPluginMixin(plugin)

"Plugin defines the middleware plugin configuration. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/plugins/"

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: obj spec.addPrefix
docs.text: "AddPrefix holds the add prefix middleware configuration. This middleware updates the path of a request before forwarding it. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/addprefix/"

docs.title: fn spec.addPrefix.withPrefix
docs.text:
withPrefix(prefix)

"Prefix is the string to add before the current path in the requested URL. It should include a leading slash (/)."

docs.title: obj spec.basicAuth
docs.text: "BasicAuth holds the basic auth middleware configuration. This middleware restricts access to your services to known users. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/basicauth/"

docs.title: fn spec.basicAuth.withHeaderField
docs.text:
withHeaderField(headerField)

"HeaderField defines a header field to store the authenticated user. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/basicauth/#headerfield"

docs.title: fn spec.basicAuth.withRealm
docs.text:
withRealm(realm)

"Realm allows the protected resources on a server to be partitioned into a set of protection spaces, each with its own authentication scheme. Default: traefik."

docs.title: fn spec.basicAuth.withRemoveHeader
docs.text:
withRemoveHeader(removeHeader)

"RemoveHeader sets the removeHeader option to true to remove the authorization header before forwarding the request to your service. Default: false."

docs.title: fn spec.basicAuth.withSecret
docs.text:
withSecret(secret)

"Secret is the name of the referenced Kubernetes Secret containing user credentials."

docs.title: obj spec.buffering
docs.text: "Buffering holds the buffering middleware configuration. This middleware retries or limits the size of requests that can be forwarded to backends. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/buffering/#maxrequestbodybytes"

docs.title: fn spec.buffering.withMaxRequestBodyBytes
docs.text:
withMaxRequestBodyBytes(maxRequestBodyBytes)

"MaxRequestBodyBytes defines the maximum allowed body size for the request (in bytes). If the request exceeds the allowed size, it is not forwarded to the service, and the client gets a 413 (Request Entity Too Large) response. Default: 0 (no maximum)."

docs.title: fn spec.buffering.withMaxResponseBodyBytes
docs.text:
withMaxResponseBodyBytes(maxResponseBodyBytes)

"MaxResponseBodyBytes defines the maximum allowed response size from the service (in bytes). If the response exceeds the allowed size, it is not forwarded to the client. The client gets a 500 (Internal Server Error) response instead. Default: 0 (no maximum)."

docs.title: fn spec.buffering.withMemRequestBodyBytes
docs.text:
withMemRequestBodyBytes(memRequestBodyBytes)

"MemRequestBodyBytes defines the threshold (in bytes) from which the request will be buffered on disk instead of in memory. Default: 1048576 (1Mi)."

docs.title: fn spec.buffering.withMemResponseBodyBytes
docs.text:
withMemResponseBodyBytes(memResponseBodyBytes)

"MemResponseBodyBytes defines the threshold (in bytes) from which the response will be buffered on disk instead of in memory. Default: 1048576 (1Mi)."

docs.title: fn spec.buffering.withRetryExpression
docs.text:
withRetryExpression(retryExpression)

"RetryExpression defines the retry conditions. It is a logical combination of functions with operators AND (&&) and OR (||). More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/buffering/#retryexpression"

docs.title: obj spec.chain
docs.text: "Chain holds the configuration of the chain middleware. This middleware enables to define reusable combinations of other pieces of middleware. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/chain/"

docs.title: fn spec.chain.withMiddlewares
docs.text:
withMiddlewares(middlewares)

"Middlewares is the list of MiddlewareRef which composes the chain."

docs.title: fn spec.chain.withMiddlewaresMixin
docs.text:
withMiddlewaresMixin(middlewares)

"Middlewares is the list of MiddlewareRef which composes the chain."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: obj spec.chain.middlewares
docs.text: "Middlewares is the list of MiddlewareRef which composes the chain."

docs.title: fn spec.chain.middlewares.withName

withName(name)

docs.title: fn spec.chain.middlewares.withNamespace

docs.title: obj spec.circuitBreaker
docs.text: "CircuitBreaker holds the circuit breaker configuration."

docs.title: fn spec.circuitBreaker.withCheckPeriod
docs.text:
withCheckPeriod(checkPeriod)

"CheckPeriod is the interval between successive checks of the circuit breaker condition (when in standby state)."

docs.title: fn spec.circuitBreaker.withExpression
docs.text:
withExpression(expression)

"Expression is the condition that triggers the tripped state."

docs.title: fn spec.circuitBreaker.withFallbackDuration
docs.text:
withFallbackDuration(fallbackDuration)

"FallbackDuration is the duration for which the circuit breaker will wait before trying to recover (from a tripped state)."

docs.title: fn spec.circuitBreaker.withRecoveryDuration
docs.text:
withRecoveryDuration(recoveryDuration)

"RecoveryDuration is the duration for which the circuit breaker will try to recover (as soon as it is in recovering state)."

docs.title: obj spec.compress
docs.text: "Compress holds the compress middleware configuration. This middleware compresses responses before sending them to the client, using gzip compression. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/compress/"

docs.title: fn spec.compress.withExcludedContentTypes
docs.text:
withExcludedContentTypes(excludedContentTypes)

"ExcludedContentTypes defines the list of content types to compare the Content-Type header of the incoming requests and responses before compressing."

docs.title: fn spec.compress.withExcludedContentTypesMixin
docs.text:
withExcludedContentTypesMixin(excludedContentTypes)

"ExcludedContentTypes defines the list of content types to compare the Content-Type header of the incoming requests and responses before compressing."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn spec.compress.withMinResponseBodyBytes
docs.text:
withMinResponseBodyBytes(minResponseBodyBytes)

"MinResponseBodyBytes defines the minimum amount of bytes a response body must have to be compressed. Default: 1024."

docs.title: obj spec.contentType
docs.text: "ContentType holds the content-type middleware configuration. This middleware exists to enable the correct behavior until at least the default one can be changed in a future version."

docs.title: fn spec.contentType.withAutoDetect
docs.text:
withAutoDetect(autoDetect)

"AutoDetect specifies whether to let the Content-Type header, if it has not been set by the backend, be automatically set to a value derived from the contents of the response. As a proxy, the default behavior should be to leave the header alone, regardless of what the backend did with it. However, the historic default was to always auto-detect and set the header if it was nil, and it is going to be kept that way in order to support users currently relying on it."

docs.title: obj spec.digestAuth
docs.text: "DigestAuth holds the digest auth middleware configuration. This middleware restricts access to your services to known users. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/digestauth/"

docs.title: fn spec.digestAuth.withHeaderField
docs.text:
withHeaderField(headerField)

"HeaderField defines a header field to store the authenticated user. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/basicauth/#headerfield"

docs.title: fn spec.digestAuth.withRealm
docs.text:
withRealm(realm)

"Realm allows the protected resources on a server to be partitioned into a set of protection spaces, each with its own authentication scheme. Default: traefik."

docs.title: fn spec.digestAuth.withRemoveHeader
docs.text:
withRemoveHeader(removeHeader)

"RemoveHeader defines whether to remove the authorization header before forwarding the request to the backend."

docs.title: fn spec.digestAuth.withSecret
docs.text:
withSecret(secret)

"Secret is the name of the referenced Kubernetes Secret containing user credentials."

docs.title: obj spec.errors
docs.text: "ErrorPage holds the custom error middleware configuration. This middleware returns a custom page in lieu of the default, according to configured ranges of HTTP Status codes. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/errorpages/"

docs.title: fn spec.errors.withQuery
docs.text:
withQuery(query)

"Query defines the URL for the error page (hosted by service). The {status} variable can be used in order to insert the status code in the URL."

docs.title: obj spec.errors.service
docs.text: "Service defines the reference to a Kubernetes Service that will serve the error page. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/errorpages/#service"

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.withKind
docs.text:
withKind(kind)

"Kind defines the kind of the Service."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.withName
docs.text:
withName(name)

"Name defines the name of the referenced Kubernetes Service or TraefikService. The differentiation between the two is specified in the Kind field."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.withNamespace
docs.text:
withNamespace(namespace)

"Namespace defines the namespace of the referenced Kubernetes Service or TraefikService."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.withNativeLB
docs.text:
withNativeLB(nativeLB)

"NativeLB controls, when creating the load-balancer, whether the LB's children are directly the pods IPs or if the only child is the Kubernetes Service clusterIP. The Kubernetes Service itself does load-balance to the pods. By default, NativeLB is false."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.withPassHostHeader
docs.text:
withPassHostHeader(passHostHeader)

"PassHostHeader defines whether the client Host header is forwarded to the upstream Kubernetes Service. By default, passHostHeader is true."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.withPort
docs.text:
withPort(port)

"Port defines the port of a Kubernetes Service. This can be a reference to a named port."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.withScheme
docs.text:
withScheme(scheme)

"Scheme defines the scheme to use for the request to the upstream Kubernetes Service. It defaults to https when Kubernetes Service port is 443, http otherwise."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.withServersTransport
docs.text:
withServersTransport(serversTransport)

"ServersTransport defines the name of ServersTransport resource to use. It allows to configure the transport between Traefik and your servers. Can only be used on a Kubernetes Service."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.withStrategy
docs.text:
withStrategy(strategy)

"Strategy defines the load balancing strategy between the servers. RoundRobin is the only supported value at the moment."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.withWeight
docs.text:
withWeight(weight)

"Weight defines the weight and should only be specified when Name references a TraefikService object (and to be precise, one that embeds a Weighted Round Robin)."

docs.title: obj spec.errors.service.responseForwarding
docs.text: "ResponseForwarding defines how Traefik forwards the response from the upstream Kubernetes Service to the client."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.responseForwarding.withFlushInterval
docs.text:
withFlushInterval(flushInterval)

"FlushInterval defines the interval, in milliseconds, in between flushes to the client while copying the response body. A negative value means to flush immediately after each write to the client. This configuration is ignored when ReverseProxy recognizes a response as a streaming response; for such responses, writes are flushed to the client immediately. Default: 100ms"

docs.title: obj spec.errors.service.sticky
docs.text: "Sticky defines the sticky sessions configuration. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/routing/services/#sticky-sessions"

docs.title: obj spec.errors.service.sticky.cookie
docs.text: "Cookie defines the sticky cookie configuration."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.sticky.cookie.withHttpOnly
docs.text:
withHttpOnly(httpOnly)

"HTTPOnly defines whether the cookie can be accessed by client-side APIs, such as JavaScript."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.sticky.cookie.withName
docs.text:
withName(name)

"Name defines the Cookie name."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.sticky.cookie.withSameSite
docs.text:
withSameSite(sameSite)

"SameSite defines the same site policy. More info: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Set-Cookie/SameSite"

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.sticky.cookie.withSecure
docs.text:
withSecure(secure)

"Secure defines whether the cookie can only be transmitted over an encrypted connection (i.e. HTTPS)."

docs.title: obj spec.forwardAuth
docs.text: "ForwardAuth holds the forward auth middleware configuration. This middleware delegates the request authentication to a Service. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/forwardauth/"

docs.title: fn spec.forwardAuth.withAddress
docs.text:
withAddress(address)

"Address defines the authentication server address."

docs.title: fn spec.forwardAuth.withAuthRequestHeaders
docs.text:
withAuthRequestHeaders(authRequestHeaders)

"AuthRequestHeaders defines the list of the headers to copy from the request to the authentication server. If not set or empty then all request headers are passed."

docs.title: fn spec.forwardAuth.withAuthRequestHeadersMixin
docs.text:
withAuthRequestHeadersMixin(authRequestHeaders)

"AuthRequestHeaders defines the list of the headers to copy from the request to the authentication server. If not set or empty then all request headers are passed."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn spec.forwardAuth.withAuthResponseHeaders
docs.text:
withAuthResponseHeaders(authResponseHeaders)

"AuthResponseHeaders defines the list of headers to copy from the authentication server response and set on forwarded request, replacing any existing conflicting headers."

docs.title: fn spec.forwardAuth.withAuthResponseHeadersMixin
docs.text:
withAuthResponseHeadersMixin(authResponseHeaders)

"AuthResponseHeaders defines the list of headers to copy from the authentication server response and set on forwarded request, replacing any existing conflicting headers."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn spec.forwardAuth.withAuthResponseHeadersRegex

docs.text:
withIsDevelopment(isDevelopment)

"IsDevelopment defines whether to mitigate the unwanted effects of the AllowedHosts, SSL, and STS options when developing. Usually testing takes place using HTTP, not HTTPS, and on localhost, not your production domain. If you would like your development environment to mimic production with complete Host blocking, SSL redirects, and STS headers, leave this as false."

docs.title: obj spec.inFlightReq
docs.text: "InFlightReq holds the in-flight request middleware configuration. This middleware limits the number of requests being processed and served concurrently. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/inflightreq/"

docs.title: fn spec.inFlightReq.withAmount
docs.text:
withAmount(amount)

"Amount defines the maximum amount of allowed simultaneous in-flight request. The middleware responds with HTTP 429 Too Many Requests if there are already amount requests in progress (based on the same sourceCriterion strategy)."

docs.title: obj spec.inFlightReq.sourceCriterion
docs.text: "SourceCriterion defines what criterion is used to group requests as originating from a common source. If several strategies are defined at the same time, an error will be raised. If none are set, the default is to use the requestHost. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/inflightreq/#sourcecriterion"

docs.title: fn spec.inFlightReq.sourceCriterion.withRequestHeaderName

"RequestHost defines whether to consider the request Host as the source."

docs.text:
withDepth(depth)

"Depth tells Traefik to use the X-Forwarded-For header and take the IP located at the depth position (starting from the right)."

docs.title: obj spec.rateLimit
docs.text: "RateLimit holds the rate limit configuration. This middleware ensures that services will receive a fair amount of requests, and allows one to define what fair is. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/ratelimit/"

docs.title: fn spec.rateLimit.withAverage
docs.text:
withAverage(average)

"Average is the maximum rate, by default in requests/s, allowed for the given source. It defaults to 0, which means no rate limiting. The rate is actually defined by dividing Average by Period. So for a rate below 1req/s, one needs to define a Period larger than a second."

docs.title: fn spec.rateLimit.withBurst
docs.text:
withBurst(burst)

"Burst is the maximum number of requests allowed to arrive in the same arbitrarily small period of time. It defaults to 1."

docs.title: fn spec.rateLimit.withPeriod
docs.text:
withPeriod(period)

"Period, in combination with Average, defines the actual maximum rate, such as: r = Average / Period. It defaults to a second."

docs.title: obj spec.rateLimit.sourceCriterion
docs.text: "SourceCriterion defines what criterion is used to group requests as originating from a common source. If several strategies are defined at the same time, an error will be raised. If none are set, the default is to use the request's remote address field (as an ipStrategy)."

docs.title: fn spec.rateLimit.sourceCriterion.withRequestHeaderName
docs.text:
withRequestHeaderName(requestHeaderName)

"RequestHeaderName defines the name of the header used to group incoming requests."

docs.title: fn spec.rateLimit.sourceCriterion.withRequestHost
docs.text:
withRequestHost(requestHost)

"RequestHost defines whether to consider the request Host as the source."

docs.title: obj spec.rateLimit.sourceCriterion.ipStrategy
docs.text: "IPStrategy holds the IP strategy configuration used by Traefik to determine the client IP. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/ipwhitelist/#ipstrategy"

docs.title: fn spec.rateLimit.sourceCriterion.ipStrategy.withDepth
docs.text:
withDepth(depth)

"Depth tells Traefik to use the X-Forwarded-For header and take the IP located at the depth position (starting from the right)."

docs.text:
withExcludedIPs(excludedIPs)

"ExcludedIPs configures Traefik to scan the X-Forwarded-For header and select the first IP not in the list."

docs.text:

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: obj spec.redirectRegex
docs.text: "RedirectRegex holds the redirect regex middleware configuration. This middleware redirects a request using regex matching and replacement. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/redirectregex/#regex"

docs.title: fn spec.redirectRegex.withPermanent
docs.text:
withPermanent(permanent)

"Permanent defines whether the redirection is permanent (301)."

docs.title: fn spec.redirectRegex.withRegex
docs.text:
withRegex(regex)

"Regex defines the regex used to match and capture elements from the request URL."

docs.title: fn spec.redirectRegex.withReplacement
docs.text:
withReplacement(replacement)

"Replacement defines how to modify the URL to have the new target URL."

docs.title: obj spec.redirectScheme
docs.text: "RedirectScheme holds the redirect scheme middleware configuration. This middleware redirects requests from a scheme/port to another. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/redirectscheme/"

docs.title: fn spec.redirectScheme.withPermanent
docs.text:
withPermanent(permanent)

"Permanent defines whether the redirection is permanent (301)."

docs.title: fn spec.redirectScheme.withPort
docs.text:
withPort(port)

"Port defines the port of the new URL."

docs.title: fn spec.redirectScheme.withScheme
docs.text:
withScheme(scheme)

"Scheme defines the scheme of the new URL."

docs.title: obj spec.replacePath
docs.text: "ReplacePath holds the replace path middleware configuration. This middleware replaces the path of the request URL and store the original path in an X-Replaced-Path header. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/replacepath/"

docs.title: fn spec.replacePath.withPath
docs.text:
withPath(path)

"Path defines the path to use as replacement in the request URL."

docs.title: obj spec.replacePathRegex
docs.text: "ReplacePathRegex holds the replace path regex middleware configuration. This middleware replaces the path of a URL using regex matching and replacement. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/replacepathregex/"

docs.title: fn spec.replacePathRegex.withRegex
docs.text:
withRegex(regex)

"Regex defines the regular expression used to match and capture the path from the request URL."

docs.title: fn spec.replacePathRegex.withReplacement
docs.text:
withReplacement(replacement)

"Replacement defines the replacement path format, which can include captured variables."

docs.title: obj spec.retry
docs.text: "Retry holds the retry middleware configuration. This middleware reissues requests a given number of times to a backend server if that server does not reply. As soon as the server answers, the middleware stops retrying, regardless of the response status. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/retry/"

docs.title: fn spec.retry.withAttempts
docs.text:
withAttempts(attempts)

"Attempts defines how many times the request should be retried."

docs.title: fn spec.retry.withInitialInterval
docs.text:
withInitialInterval(initialInterval)

"InitialInterval defines the first wait time in the exponential backoff series. The maximum interval is calculated as twice the initialInterval. If unspecified, requests will be retried immediately. The value of initialInterval should be provided in seconds or as a valid duration format, see https://pkg.go.dev/time#ParseDuration."

docs.title: obj spec.stripPrefix
docs.text: "StripPrefix holds the strip prefix middleware configuration. This middleware removes the specified prefixes from the URL path. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/stripprefix/"

docs.title: fn spec.stripPrefix.withForceSlash
docs.text:
withForceSlash(forceSlash)

"ForceSlash ensures that the resulting stripped path is not the empty string, by replacing it with / when necessary. Default: true."

docs.title: fn spec.stripPrefix.withPrefixes
docs.text:
withPrefixes(prefixes)

"Prefixes defines the prefixes to strip from the request URL."

docs.title: fn spec.stripPrefix.withPrefixesMixin
docs.text:
withPrefixesMixin(prefixes)

"Prefixes defines the prefixes to strip from the request URL."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn spec.stripPrefixRegex.withRegex
docs.text:
withRegex(regex)

"Regex defines the regular expression to match the path prefix from the request URL."

docs.title: fn spec.stripPrefixRegex.withRegexMixin
docs.text:
withRegexMixin(regex)

"Regex defines the regular expression to match the path prefix from the request URL."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withClusterName
docs.text:
withClusterName(clusterName)

"The name of the cluster which the object belongs to. This is used to distinguish resources with same name and namespace in different clusters. This field is not set anywhere right now and apiserver is going to ignore it if set in create or update request."

docs.title: fn metadata.withCreationTimestamp
docs.text:
withCreationTimestamp(creationTimestamp)

"Time is a wrapper around time.Time which supports correct marshaling to YAML and JSON. Wrappers are provided for many of the factory methods that the time package offers."

docs.title: fn metadata.withDeletionGracePeriodSeconds
docs.text:
withDeletionGracePeriodSeconds(deletionGracePeriodSeconds)

"Number of seconds allowed for this object to gracefully terminate before it will be removed from the system. Only set when deletionTimestamp is also set. May only be shortened. Read-only."

docs.title: fn metadata.withDeletionTimestamp
docs.text:
withDeletionTimestamp(deletionTimestamp)

"Time is a wrapper around time.Time which supports correct marshaling to YAML and JSON. Wrappers are provided for many of the factory methods that the time package offers."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizersMixin
docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withGeneration
docs.text:
withGeneration(generation)

"A sequence number representing a specific generation of the desired state. Populated by the system. Read-only."

docs.title: fn metadata.withLabels
docs.text:
withLabels(labels)

"Map of string keys and values that can be used to organize and categorize (scope and select) objects. May match selectors of replication controllers and services. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/labels"

docs.title: fn metadata.withLabelsMixin
docs.text:
withLabelsMixin(labels)

"Map of string keys and values that can be used to organize and categorize (scope and select) objects. May match selectors of replication controllers and services. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/labels"

docs.title: fn metadata.withName
docs.text:
withName(name)

"Name must be unique within a namespace. Is required when creating resources, although some resources may allow a client to request the generation of an appropriate name automatically. Name is primarily intended for creation idempotence and configuration definition. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#names"

docs.title: fn metadata.withNamespace
docs.text:
withNamespace(namespace)

"Namespace defines the space within which each name must be unique. An empty namespace is equivalent to the \"default\" namespace, but \"default\" is the canonical representation. Not all objects are required to be scoped to a namespace - the value of this field for those objects will be empty.\n\nMust be a DNS_LABEL. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/namespaces"

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferences
docs.text:
withOwnerReferences(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferencesMixin
docs.text:
withOwnerReferencesMixin(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withResourceVersion
docs.text:
withResourceVersion(resourceVersion)

"An opaque value that represents the internal version of this object that can be used by clients to determine when objects have changed. May be used for optimistic concurrency, change detection, and the watch operation on a resource or set of resources. Clients must treat these values as opaque and passed unmodified back to the server. They may only be valid for a particular resource or set of resources.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. Value must be treated as opaque by clients and . More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#concurrency-control-and-consistency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withSelfLink
docs.text:
withSelfLink(selfLink)

"SelfLink is a URL representing this object. Populated by the system. Read-only.\n\nDEPRECATED Kubernetes will stop propagating this field in 1.20 release and the field is planned to be removed in 1.21 release."

docs.title: fn metadata.withUid
docs.text:
withUid(uid)

"UID is the unique in time and space value for this object. It is typically generated by the server on successful creation of a resource and is not allowed to change on PUT operations.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#uids"

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizersMixin
docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

withFlushInterval(flushInterval)

"FlushInterval defines the interval, in milliseconds, in between flushes to the client while copying the response body. A negative value means to flush immediately after each write to the client. This configuration is ignored when ReverseProxy recognizes a response as a streaming response; for such responses, writes are flushed to the client immediately. Default: 100ms"

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizersMixin
docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizersMixin
docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

withClusterName(clusterName)

"Time is a wrapper around time.Time which supports correct marshaling to YAML and JSON. Wrappers are provided for many of the factory methods that the time package offers."

withDeletionGracePeriodSeconds(deletionGracePeriodSeconds)

"Number of seconds allowed for this object to gracefully terminate before it will be removed from the system. Only set when deletionTimestamp is also set. May only be shortened. Read-only."

docs.title: fn metadata.withDeletionTimestamp

withDeletionTimestamp(deletionTimestamp)

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizersMixin
docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withGeneration
docs.text:
withGeneration(generation)

"A sequence number representing a specific generation of the desired state. Populated by the system. Read-only."

docs.title: fn metadata.withLabels
docs.text:
withLabels(labels)

"Map of string keys and values that can be used to organize and categorize (scope and select) objects. May match selectors of replication controllers and services. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/labels"

docs.title: fn metadata.withLabelsMixin
docs.text:
withLabelsMixin(labels)

"Map of string keys and values that can be used to organize and categorize (scope and select) objects. May match selectors of replication controllers and services. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/labels"

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withName
docs.text:
withName(name)

"Name must be unique within a namespace. Is required when creating resources, although some resources may allow a client to request the generation of an appropriate name automatically. Name is primarily intended for creation idempotence and configuration definition. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#names"

docs.title: fn metadata.withNamespace
docs.text:
withNamespace(namespace)

"Namespace defines the space within which each name must be unique. An empty namespace is equivalent to the \"default\" namespace, but \"default\" is the canonical representation. Not all objects are required to be scoped to a namespace - the value of this field for those objects will be empty.\n\nMust be a DNS_LABEL. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/namespaces"

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferences
docs.text:
withOwnerReferences(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferencesMixin
docs.text:
withOwnerReferencesMixin(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withResourceVersion
docs.text:
withResourceVersion(resourceVersion)

"An opaque value that represents the internal version of this object that can be used by clients to determine when objects have changed. May be used for optimistic concurrency, change detection, and the watch operation on a resource or set of resources. Clients must treat these values as opaque and passed unmodified back to the server. They may only be valid for a particular resource or set of resources.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. Value must be treated as opaque by clients and . More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#concurrency-control-and-consistency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withSelfLink
docs.text:
withSelfLink(selfLink)

"SelfLink is a URL representing this object. Populated by the system. Read-only.\n\nDEPRECATED Kubernetes will stop propagating this field in 1.20 release and the field is planned to be removed in 1.21 release."

docs.title: fn metadata.withUid
docs.text:
withUid(uid)

"UID is the unique in time and space value for this object. It is typically generated by the server on successful creation of a resource and is not allowed to change on PUT operations.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#uids"

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferencesMixin
docs.text:
withOwnerReferencesMixin(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withResourceVersion
docs.text:
withResourceVersion(resourceVersion)

"An opaque value that represents the internal version of this object that can be used by clients to determine when objects have changed. May be used for optimistic concurrency, change detection, and the watch operation on a resource or set of resources. Clients must treat these values as opaque and passed unmodified back to the server. They may only be valid for a particular resource or set of resources.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. Value must be treated as opaque by clients and . More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#concurrency-control-and-consistency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withSelfLink
docs.text:
withSelfLink(selfLink)

"SelfLink is a URL representing this object. Populated by the system. Read-only.\n\nDEPRECATED Kubernetes will stop propagating this field in 1.20 release and the field is planned to be removed in 1.21 release."

docs.title: fn metadata.withUid
docs.text:
withUid(uid)

"UID is the unique in time and space value for this object. It is typically generated by the server on successful creation of a resource and is not allowed to change on PUT operations.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#uids"

docs.title: obj spec
docs.text: "MiddlewareSpec defines the desired state of a Middleware."

docs.title: fn spec.withPlugin
docs.text:
withPlugin(plugin)

"Plugin defines the middleware plugin configuration. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/plugins/"

docs.title: fn spec.withPluginMixin
docs.text:
withPluginMixin(plugin)

"Plugin defines the middleware plugin configuration. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/plugins/"

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: obj spec.addPrefix
docs.text: "AddPrefix holds the add prefix middleware configuration. This middleware updates the path of a request before forwarding it. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/addprefix/"

docs.title: fn spec.addPrefix.withPrefix
docs.text:
withPrefix(prefix)

"Prefix is the string to add before the current path in the requested URL. It should include a leading slash (/)."

docs.title: obj spec.basicAuth
docs.text: "BasicAuth holds the basic auth middleware configuration. This middleware restricts access to your services to known users. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/basicauth/"

docs.title: fn spec.basicAuth.withHeaderField
docs.text:
withHeaderField(headerField)

"HeaderField defines a header field to store the authenticated user. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/basicauth/#headerfield"

docs.title: fn spec.basicAuth.withRealm
docs.text:
withRealm(realm)

"Realm allows the protected resources on a server to be partitioned into a set of protection spaces, each with its own authentication scheme. Default: traefik."

docs.title: fn spec.basicAuth.withRemoveHeader
docs.text:
withRemoveHeader(removeHeader)

"RemoveHeader sets the removeHeader option to true to remove the authorization header before forwarding the request to your service. Default: false."

docs.title: fn spec.basicAuth.withSecret
docs.text:
withSecret(secret)

"Secret is the name of the referenced Kubernetes Secret containing user credentials."

docs.title: obj spec.buffering
docs.text: "Buffering holds the buffering middleware configuration. This middleware retries or limits the size of requests that can be forwarded to backends. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/buffering/#maxrequestbodybytes"

docs.title: fn spec.buffering.withMaxRequestBodyBytes
docs.text:
withMaxRequestBodyBytes(maxRequestBodyBytes)

"MaxRequestBodyBytes defines the maximum allowed body size for the request (in bytes). If the request exceeds the allowed size, it is not forwarded to the service, and the client gets a 413 (Request Entity Too Large) response. Default: 0 (no maximum)."

docs.title: fn spec.buffering.withMaxResponseBodyBytes
docs.text:
withMaxResponseBodyBytes(maxResponseBodyBytes)

"MaxResponseBodyBytes defines the maximum allowed response size from the service (in bytes). If the response exceeds the allowed size, it is not forwarded to the client. The client gets a 500 (Internal Server Error) response instead. Default: 0 (no maximum)."

docs.title: fn spec.buffering.withMemRequestBodyBytes
docs.text:
withMemRequestBodyBytes(memRequestBodyBytes)

"MemRequestBodyBytes defines the threshold (in bytes) from which the request will be buffered on disk instead of in memory. Default: 1048576 (1Mi)."

docs.title: fn spec.buffering.withMemResponseBodyBytes
docs.text:
withMemResponseBodyBytes(memResponseBodyBytes)

"MemResponseBodyBytes defines the threshold (in bytes) from which the response will be buffered on disk instead of in memory. Default: 1048576 (1Mi)."

docs.title: fn spec.buffering.withRetryExpression
docs.text:
withRetryExpression(retryExpression)

"RetryExpression defines the retry conditions. It is a logical combination of functions with operators AND (&&) and OR (||). More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/buffering/#retryexpression"

docs.title: obj spec.chain
docs.text: "Chain holds the configuration of the chain middleware. This middleware enables to define reusable combinations of other pieces of middleware. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/chain/"

docs.title: fn spec.chain.withMiddlewares
docs.text:
withMiddlewares(middlewares)

"Middlewares is the list of MiddlewareRef which composes the chain."

docs.title: fn spec.chain.withMiddlewaresMixin

withMiddlewaresMixin(middlewares)

"Middlewares is the list of MiddlewareRef which composes the chain."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: obj spec.chain.middlewares
docs.text: "Middlewares is the list of MiddlewareRef which composes the chain."

docs.title: fn spec.chain.middlewares.withName

withCheckPeriod(checkPeriod)

docs.title: fn spec.circuitBreaker.withExpression

withExpression(expression)

docs.title: fn spec.circuitBreaker.withFallbackDuration
docs.text:
withFallbackDuration(fallbackDuration)

"FallbackDuration is the duration for which the circuit breaker will wait before trying to recover (from a tripped state)."

docs.title: fn spec.circuitBreaker.withRecoveryDuration
docs.text:
withRecoveryDuration(recoveryDuration)

"RecoveryDuration is the duration for which the circuit breaker will try to recover (as soon as it is in recovering state)."

docs.title: obj spec.compress
docs.text: "Compress holds the compress middleware configuration. This middleware compresses responses before sending them to the client, using gzip compression. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/compress/"

docs.title: fn spec.compress.withExcludedContentTypes
docs.text:
withExcludedContentTypes(excludedContentTypes)

"ExcludedContentTypes defines the list of content types to compare the Content-Type header of the incoming requests and responses before compressing."

docs.title: fn spec.compress.withExcludedContentTypesMixin
docs.text:
withExcludedContentTypesMixin(excludedContentTypes)

"ExcludedContentTypes defines the list of content types to compare the Content-Type header of the incoming requests and responses before compressing."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn spec.compress.withMinResponseBodyBytes
docs.text:
withMinResponseBodyBytes(minResponseBodyBytes)

"MinResponseBodyBytes defines the minimum amount of bytes a response body must have to be compressed. Default: 1024."

docs.title: obj spec.contentType
docs.text: "ContentType holds the content-type middleware configuration. This middleware exists to enable the correct behavior until at least the default one can be changed in a future version."

docs.title: fn spec.contentType.withAutoDetect
docs.text:
withAutoDetect(autoDetect)

"AutoDetect specifies whether to let the Content-Type header, if it has not been set by the backend, be automatically set to a value derived from the contents of the response. As a proxy, the default behavior should be to leave the header alone, regardless of what the backend did with it. However, the historic default was to always auto-detect and set the header if it was nil, and it is going to be kept that way in order to support users currently relying on it."

docs.title: obj spec.digestAuth
docs.text: "DigestAuth holds the digest auth middleware configuration. This middleware restricts access to your services to known users. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/digestauth/"

docs.title: fn spec.digestAuth.withHeaderField
docs.text:
withHeaderField(headerField)

"HeaderField defines a header field to store the authenticated user. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/basicauth/#headerfield"

docs.title: fn spec.digestAuth.withRealm
docs.text:
withRealm(realm)

"Realm allows the protected resources on a server to be partitioned into a set of protection spaces, each with its own authentication scheme. Default: traefik."

docs.title: fn spec.digestAuth.withRemoveHeader
docs.text:
withRemoveHeader(removeHeader)

"RemoveHeader defines whether to remove the authorization header before forwarding the request to the backend."

docs.title: fn spec.digestAuth.withSecret
docs.text:
withSecret(secret)

"Secret is the name of the referenced Kubernetes Secret containing user credentials."

docs.title: obj spec.errors
docs.text: "ErrorPage holds the custom error middleware configuration. This middleware returns a custom page in lieu of the default, according to configured ranges of HTTP Status codes. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/errorpages/"

docs.title: fn spec.errors.withQuery
docs.text:
withQuery(query)

"Query defines the URL for the error page (hosted by service). The {status} variable can be used in order to insert the status code in the URL."

docs.title: obj spec.errors.service
docs.text: "Service defines the reference to a Kubernetes Service that will serve the error page. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/errorpages/#service"

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.withKind
docs.text:
withKind(kind)

"Kind defines the kind of the Service."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.withName
docs.text:
withName(name)

"Name defines the name of the referenced Kubernetes Service or TraefikService. The differentiation between the two is specified in the Kind field."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.withNamespace
docs.text:
withNamespace(namespace)

"Namespace defines the namespace of the referenced Kubernetes Service or TraefikService."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.withNativeLB
docs.text:
withNativeLB(nativeLB)

"NativeLB controls, when creating the load-balancer, whether the LB's children are directly the pods IPs or if the only child is the Kubernetes Service clusterIP. The Kubernetes Service itself does load-balance to the pods. By default, NativeLB is false."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.withPassHostHeader
docs.text:
withPassHostHeader(passHostHeader)

"PassHostHeader defines whether the client Host header is forwarded to the upstream Kubernetes Service. By default, passHostHeader is true."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.withPort
docs.text:
withPort(port)

"Port defines the port of a Kubernetes Service. This can be a reference to a named port."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.withScheme
docs.text:
withScheme(scheme)

"Scheme defines the scheme to use for the request to the upstream Kubernetes Service. It defaults to https when Kubernetes Service port is 443, http otherwise."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.withServersTransport
docs.text:
withServersTransport(serversTransport)

"ServersTransport defines the name of ServersTransport resource to use. It allows to configure the transport between Traefik and your servers. Can only be used on a Kubernetes Service."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.withStrategy
docs.text:
withStrategy(strategy)

"Strategy defines the load balancing strategy between the servers. RoundRobin is the only supported value at the moment."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.withWeight
docs.text:
withWeight(weight)

"Weight defines the weight and should only be specified when Name references a TraefikService object (and to be precise, one that embeds a Weighted Round Robin)."

docs.title: obj spec.errors.service.responseForwarding
docs.text: "ResponseForwarding defines how Traefik forwards the response from the upstream Kubernetes Service to the client."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.responseForwarding.withFlushInterval
docs.text:
withFlushInterval(flushInterval)

"FlushInterval defines the interval, in milliseconds, in between flushes to the client while copying the response body. A negative value means to flush immediately after each write to the client. This configuration is ignored when ReverseProxy recognizes a response as a streaming response; for such responses, writes are flushed to the client immediately. Default: 100ms"

docs.title: obj spec.errors.service.sticky
docs.text: "Sticky defines the sticky sessions configuration. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/routing/services/#sticky-sessions"

docs.title: obj spec.errors.service.sticky.cookie
docs.text: "Cookie defines the sticky cookie configuration."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.sticky.cookie.withHttpOnly
docs.text:
withHttpOnly(httpOnly)

"HTTPOnly defines whether the cookie can be accessed by client-side APIs, such as JavaScript."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.sticky.cookie.withName
docs.text:
withName(name)

"Name defines the Cookie name."

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.sticky.cookie.withSameSite
docs.text:
withSameSite(sameSite)

"SameSite defines the same site policy. More info: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Set-Cookie/SameSite"

docs.title: fn spec.errors.service.sticky.cookie.withSecure
docs.text:
withSecure(secure)

"Secure defines whether the cookie can only be transmitted over an encrypted connection (i.e. HTTPS)."

docs.title: obj spec.forwardAuth
docs.text: "ForwardAuth holds the forward auth middleware configuration. This middleware delegates the request authentication to a Service. More info: https://doc.traefik.io/traefik/v2.10/middlewares/http/forwardauth/"

docs.text:

withAccessControlAllowOriginListRegexMixin(accessControlAllowOriginListRegex)

withCustomFrameOptionsValue(customFrameOptionsValue)

withCustomRequestHeaders(customRequestHeaders)

docs.title: fn spec.headers.withCustomRequestHeadersMixin

withCustomRequestHeadersMixin(customRequestHeaders)

withCustomResponseHeaders(customResponseHeaders)

docs.title: fn spec.headers.withForceSTSHeader
docs.text:
withForceSTSHeader(forceSTSHeader)

docs.title: fn spec.headers.withFrameDeny

withFrameDeny(frameDeny)

withHostsProxyHeaders(hostsProxyHeaders)

docs.title: fn spec.headers.withHostsProxyHeadersMixin
